centralQuestion: Should New York City implement rent controls?

reasons.description: Rent control can keep housing affordable in a city where median asking rents have repeatedly hit record highs, helping lower‑income tenants avoid displacement.

sources.title: The Guardian: "I was on New York's rent board. Zohran Mamdani's ideas aren't pie in the sky"
Brookings Institution: "Ten economic facts about rental housing"

reasons.description: By reducing turnover, rent stabilization helps preserve neighborhood cohesion and prevents the social costs of frequent moves.

sources.title: Urban Institute: "Rent Control: Key Policy Components and Their Equity Implications"

reasons.description: Regulation can rebalance bargaining power between landlords and tenants, a goal tenant‑rights groups say is essential for housing equity.

sources.title: Economic Policy Institute: "Scapegoating Rent Control: Masking the Causes of Homelessness"

objections.description: Price ceilings discourage new construction and lead owners to withdraw units, shrinking the overall rental supply.

sources.title: The Wall Street Journal: "How to Kill New York's Rental Housing Market"
Reuters: "Mamdani’s 'Millionaire Tax' and Other Financial Fallacies"

objections.description: Tighter rent caps can erode landlords’ revenue, leading to deferred maintenance and lower housing quality in regulated units.

sources.title: Reuters: "NYCB turnaround faces rocky road as commercial real estate exposure drags"
American Enterprise Institute: "Rent control 'Shabbifying' NY's Housing As Owners Feel the Squeeze"

objections.description: Economists warn that limiting some rents can push prices higher in the unregulated sector, unintentionally raising average market rents.

sources.title: American Enterprise Institute: "Zohran Mamdani's rent freeze will warp NYC's housing market and hurt us all"

expertPerspectives.name: Howard Husock
expertPerspectives.description: Howard Husock is a Senior Fellow at the American Enterprise Institute. https://www.aei.org/op-eds/zohran-mamdanis-rent-freeze-will-warp-nycs-housing-market-and-hurt-us-all/

research.title: “The Effects of Rent Control Expansion on Tenants, Landlords, and Inequality: Evidence from San Francisco” – American Economic Review (2019)
research.description: Shows rent control reduced displacement but cut rental supply by 15 %, highlighting supply‑side trade‑offs.

research.title: “Rent Control and Tenants’ Benefits: Stability or Affordability? Evidence from New York City” – SSRN working paper (2023)
research.description: Uses NYC panel data to examine whether rent‑stabilized households gain more from stability or price discounts.

research.title: “Measuring the Value of Rent Stabilization and Understanding Its Distributional Impact across NYC” – Journal of Housing Economics (2023)
research.description: Estimates an average $410 monthly discount for stabilized units but finds benefits skew toward higher‑income neighborhoods.

research.title: “Rent‑control effects through the lens of empirical research” – Regional Science and Urban Economics (2024)
research.description: Comprehensive literature review synthesizing empirical findings on economic and distributional impacts of rent regulation.
